title: Retrotransposon methylation and activity in wild fish (A. anguilla): A matter of size *

affiliation.institution: Observatoire Aquitain des Sciences de l'Univers

location.addrLine: UMS 2567 POREA, All ee Geoffroy Saint Hilaire

abstract: Understanding how organisms cope with global change is a major question in many fields of biology. Mainly, understanding the molecular mechanisms supporting rapid phenotypic changes of organisms in response to stress and linking stress-induced molecular events to adaptive or adverse outcomes at the individual or population levels remain a major challenge in evolutionary biology, ecology or ecotoxicology. In this view, the present study aimed to test (i) whether environmental factors, especially pollutants, can trigger changes in the activity of retrotransposons (RTs) in wild fish and (ii) if changes in RT DNA methylation or transcription levels can be linked to modifications at the individual level. RTs are genetic elements that have the ability to replicate and integrate elsewhere in the genome. Although RTs are mainly quiescent during normal development, they can be experimentally activated under lifethreatening conditions, affecting the fitness of their host. Wild eels were collected in four sampling sites presenting differing levels of contamination. The methylation level and the transcriptional activity of two RTs and two genes involved in development and cell differentiation were analyzed in fish liver in addition to the determination of fish contaminants levels and diverse growth and morphometric indices. An up-regulation of RTs associated to lower methylation levels and lower growth indices were observed in highly contaminated fish. Our results suggest that RT activation in fish experiencing stress conditions could have both detrimental and beneficial implications, affecting fish growth but promoting resistance to environmental stressors such as pollutants.

abstract.text: Understanding how organisms cope with global change is a major question in many fields of biology. Mainly, understanding the molecular mechanisms supporting rapid phenotypic changes of organisms in response to stress and linking stress-induced molecular events to adaptive or adverse outcomes at the individual or population levels remain a major challenge in evolutionary biology, ecology or ecotoxicology. In this view, the present study aimed to test (i) whether environmental factors, especially pollutants, can trigger changes in the activity of retrotransposons (RTs) in wild fish and (ii) if changes in RT DNA methylation or transcription levels can be linked to modifications at the individual level. RTs are genetic elements that have the ability to replicate and integrate elsewhere in the genome. Although RTs are mainly quiescent during normal development, they can be experimentally activated under lifethreatening conditions, affecting the fitness of their host. Wild eels were collected in four sampling sites presenting differing levels of contamination. The methylation level and the transcriptional activity of two RTs and two genes involved in development and cell differentiation were analyzed in fish liver in addition to the determination of fish contaminants levels and diverse growth and morphometric indices. An up-regulation of RTs associated to lower methylation levels and lower growth indices were observed in highly contaminated fish. Our results suggest that RT activation in fish experiencing stress conditions could have both detrimental and beneficial implications, affecting fish growth but promoting resistance to environmental stressors such as pollutants.

body_text.text: Transposable elements (TEs) are DNA sequences that have the ability to replicate, to move and to integrate elsewhere in the genome. There are two main classes of TEs, (i) retrotransposons (RTs) that transpose via an RNA intermediate and (ii) DNA transposons that transpose directly without RNA intermediate. Three major orders of RTs are distinguished: long terminal repeats (LTR) RTs, long interspersed elements (LINEs) and short interspersed elements (SINEs). These RTs accumulate in the genome via a copy-and-paste mechanism and can constitute a substantial proportion of the genome (Elbarbary et al., 2016) . For example, SINEs and LINEs constitute 30% of the human genome (Lander et al., 2001) . TEs have long been considered as "selfish" or "parasitic" DNA elements since active TEs are known to be highly mutagenic and to impair the fitness of their host (Slotkin and Martienssen, 2007) . The role of TEs in genome evolution, microevolution and transcription regulation has received increasing attention in recent years (Federoff, 2012; Casacuberta and Gonz alez, 2013; Faulkner et al., 2009; Rey et al., 2016) . RTs are non-randomly distributed in genomes and new insertions of these elements in the genome can provide alternative promoters for genes (Lander et al., 2001; Faulkner et al., 2009) . Moreover, an emerging body of evidence indicates that RTs can directly regulate gene expression at different molecular levels, by acting on the chromatin structure, gene transcription, pre-mRNA processing and mRNA metabolism (Elbarbary et al., 2016) . Thus, TEs can shape the transcriptome of cells via mechanisms acting at both the genomic and transcriptional levels. In addition, although RTs are mostly inactive in their hosts, they are activated during specific stages of development, mainly during early embryogenesis but also later at the adult stage during cell fate and reprogramming or in response to stress (Fedoroff, 2012; Hutchins and Pei, 2015; Hunter et al., 2012; Capy et al., 2000; Martínez and Slotkin, 2012) .
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: DNA methylation, which refers to the addition of a methyl group to cytosine to form the 5-methylcytosine base, is an epigenetic mechanism commonly associated with "gene silencing", i.e. transcriptional repression (with few exceptions Vandegehuchte and Janssen, 2011) . In a previous work, we reported changes in the DNA methylation status of RT-like sequences in the liver of European eels (Anguilla anguilla) experimentally exposed to Cd. These changes were associated with changes in the transcriptional activity of neighboring genes (Pierron et al., 2014a) . In another work carried out on the liver of wild eels collected in sites presenting different levels of pollution, we reported changes in the transcription level of genes involved in cell differentiation, development and epigenetic mechanisms in contaminated eels (Baillon et al., 2016) . Since (i) RTs are known to be activated by abiotic and biotic stress or during cell reprogramming in the somatic tissues of adult animals and (ii) major mechanisms responsible for the regulation of TEs transcription and transposition are DNA methylation and histone methylation (i.e. epigenetic mechanisms (Hutchins and Pei, 2015; Fedoroff, 2012) ), the present work was carried out to test the hypothesis that in situ chronic exposure to pollutants can induce changes in the methylation and/or the activity of RTs in the liver of wild fish.
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: We measured the DNA methylation and the transcription level of a LINE (UnaL2) and a SINE (UnaSINE) in wild European eels captured in four sampling sites selected on the basis of their known gradient of contamination by metallic and organic pollutants (previous data published in Baillon et al., 2015; Laporte et al., 2016 and Pannetier et al., 2016) . Rather than performing analyses at the genomic level, we analyzed these three elements at the epigenetic and RNA levels. Indeed, if RTs were found to be activated by abiotic stressors mainly during experimental investigations, it remains unknown when TEs are activated or what triggers TE activation in nature (Matsunaga et al., 2015) . Moreover, because of accumulated mutations or truncation, most RTs present in a genome are no longer able to retrotranspose. However, recent works suggest that such non-coding RTderived sequences can modulate cell gene expression (e.g. lncRNAs (Hutchins and Pei, 2015) ) playing a key role in phenotypic plasticity (Rey et al., 2016; Aubin-Horth and Renn, 2009) . In addition, although numerous studies were carried out, notably in fish, to study the genome dynamics and chromosomal localization of RTs, studies investigating the methylation and/or the transcription level of RTs in wild animals remain scarce (Barbosa et al., 2014) . Finally, recent evidences support that TEs and epigenetic components jointly constitute a molecular engine triggering rapid adaptive phenotypic responses to environmental changes. Thus, our study also aimed at testing whether environmental factors (mainly pollutants) can trigger RT activation and whether this activation can have longlasting effects on animals, not in an evolutionary perspective, which has already received a lot of attention (Casacuberta and Gonz alez, 2013; Zeh et al., 2009) but rather at the physiological and individual levels. In order to link potential changes in RT DNA methylation and transcription levels to environmental factors and phenotypic traits, we measured the contamination levels of eels as well as different morphometric and growth indices. Finally, as RTs are known to be activated during cell fate and reprogramming, we measured the transcription level of two genes involved in cell differentiation or in the survival and maintenance of stem/progenitor cells, the arginine-glutamic acid dipeptide repeats protein (Zoltewicz et al., 2003) (rere) and the transcription factor SOX-6 (Baillon et al., 2016; Abdelalim et al., 2014; Ohta et al., 2013) (sox6) . Analyses were carried out in liver samples due to the key role of this organ in energy metabolism and fish growth, as well as in xenobiotic and metallic detoxification (Fuentes et al., 2013) . The gene rere was previously found to be up-regulated in wild contaminated eels (Baillon et al., 2016) . Moreover, in this previous paper, we hypothesized that cellular differentiation and stem/progenitor liver cells could be involved in the adaptive response developed by eels chronically exposed to pollutant mixtures. Cellular differentiation induces significant changes in the phenotype of cells, from their shape to their metabolic activity and their responsiveness to external and internal stimuli (Miyajima et al., 2014) . The gene sox6 was also analyzed as sox gene family members are representative of stemness-related genes (Ohta et al., 2013; Lin et al., 2015) .
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: As part of the ANR IMMORTEEL program, 32 European eels (Anguilla anguilla) were captured from four French sampling sites, (i) comprising a reference site and three sites presenting differing levels of metal and organic contamination (see Baillon et al., 2015; Laporte et al., 2016 and Pannetier et al., 2016 for more details), and (ii) presenting a wide range of physiochemical conditions (Table 1) : Table 1 Morphometric measures (mean ± SE, n ¼ 8) and sex of eels captured in four sampling sites (CER, GIR, GAR, DOR) and environmental factors determined in each sampling site. Means sharing same-case letters do not differ significantly (P > 0.05). Certes salt marshes (considered as a reference site; CER; 44 41 0 18 00 N; 1 1 0 39 00 W), the Gironde estuary (GIR; 45 12 0 07 00 N; 0 43 0 35 00 W), the Garonne river (GAR; 44 43 0 51 00 N; 0 28 0 05 00 W) and the Dordogne river (DOR, 44 0 05 00 N; 0 08 0 25 00 W). These four sites are located within a distance of 37 km (Fig. 1 ). Fish were collected during ten consecutive days, May 22 to 31 of 2012, using a trawl or a fyke net. For each sampling site, a total of eight immature yellow eels were collected and used for subsequent analyses. Fish were dissected as soon as possible at the proximity of the sampling site and organs (liver and muscle) were divided into several samples. Samples for DNA methylation and transcription analyses were stored in RNA later at À20 C until needed. For both organic and metal analyses, samples were stored at À80 C. For all sites, temperature, salinity and dissolved oxygen concentrations were determined using a multi-parameter portable device at 1 m under the surface and by using data coming from the automated observation network of the Gironde (MAGEST network).
body_text.section: Wild eel sample collection

body_text.text: The sex of animals was determined macroscopically during the dissection and was further validated by histological investigations as described in Pierron et al. (2014b) . Only females and undifferentiated animals were sampled and used.
body_text.section: Sex determination, morphometric and growth indices

body_text.text: The total length and weight of fish were recorded for each fish in order to estimate the Fulton condition factor [K ¼ (total weight (g))/ (total length (cm)) 3 ) x 10 5 ], the Hepato-Somatic Index [HSI¼ (weight liver/total weight) x 100] and the Spleen Somatic Index [SSI ¼ (spleen weight/total weight) x 100]. We also determined the Ocular Index (OI), which reflects changes in eye diameters and has proven to be a useful criterion for assessing the degree of maturation/silvering in eels (Pankhurst, 1982) .
body_text.section: Sex determination, morphometric and growth indices

body_text.text: Age determination was carried out by otolithometry as detailed in Patey et al. (2018) . Back calculation was undertaken by using the biological intercept procedure as described in Patey et al. (2018) . The growth rate at capture (GR) was calculated by dividing the measured body length (BL) by the age at capture. We also determined a growth coefficient (GC) as a proxy of growth potential throughout the life of animal that was less influenced by age and length at capture by determining the slope of the regression line between back-calculated body length (y axis) and age (x axis) (correlation coefficient R 2 ¼ 0.98 ± 0.04, mean ± SE, n ¼ 32). Indeed the annual growth rate in length in eels decreases gradually with age, i.e. growth in length being maximal and linear during their early life (details in Patey et al., 2018) . Concomitantly, we also used the back-calculated body length at 1, 2 and 3 years of life (all sampled eels presented an age at capture superior to 3).
body_text.section: Sex determination, morphometric and growth indices

body_text.text: Analysis of the seven indicators PCBs (polychloro-biphenyls; CB50 þ 28, CB52, CB101, CB118, CB138, CB153, and CB180) and 14 OCPs (organochlorine pesticides; hexachlorobenzene or HCB, lindane or g-HCH, dieldrin, heptachlor, heptaclorepoxide, cischlordane, trans-nonachlor, mirex, and DDTs) were performed on muscle samples following the procedures described in Baillon et al. (2015) and Laporte et al. (2016) . The data inferior to the LQs were not used and are not presented. For PCBs, LQs were comprised between 0.2 ng/g dw and 2 ng/g dw; for OCPs they were comprised between 0.1 ng/g dw and 0.4 ng/g dw. Metal concentrations were measured from liver samples following the procedures described in Pannetier et al. (2016) .
body_text.section: Metal and organic concentration analyses

body_text.text: To design specific primer pairs, the sequences of the long interspersed nuclear element UnaL2 and short interspersed nuclear element UnaSINE1 from Anguilla japonica were used (Kajikawa et al., 2005) . All these sequences were compared and aligned to the genome of A. Anguilla (Henkel et al., 2012 ) (genome assembly containing 923 Mbp of scaffolds with a length-weighed median fragment length (N50) of 78 Kbp and 179 Mbp of contigs, which are very small or highly repetitive) using Blast algorithm (Evalue threshold 10 À10 ) and BioEdit software. Among the numerous copies of each RT sequence in the A. anguilla genome, we then searched for the most conserved regions. Finally, these highly conserved regions were used to create a consensus sequence and design specific primers in different parts of the RTs (Fig. S1 ) by means of the Pri-mer3plus software for quantitative RT PCR analysis and using the Pyromark assay design software for pyrosequencing analysis (Table S1 ). Concerning quantitative RT PCR analysis, for UnaL2, specific primers were designed in the 5 0 UTR (containing an internal promoter), 3 0 UTR (containing a stem-loop region required for retrotransposition) and in the unique ORF (containing an endonuclease and a reverse transcriptase) (Kajikawa et al., 2005) . For UnaSINE, specific primers were designed in the region a (containing internal promoter region) and in the region c (a region that corresponds to the stem-loop region of UnaL2). For the other genes investigated (b-actin, rere and sox6), sequences were obtained from two A. anguilla transcriptomic databases; ZF-Genomics (Henkel et al., 2012) and from our previous investigations (Baillon et al., 2015 (Baillon et al., , 2016 . Primers were designed using the Primer3plus software (Table S1 ). Concerning pyrosequencing analyses, specific primers (Table S1 ) were designed to amplify a short fragment located in the upstream part of the 5 0 UTR Region of UnaL2 and in the Region an of UnaSINE.
body_text.section: Genetic data treatment

body_text.text: We also searched to identify the function of the coding regions located at the proximity of UnaL2 and UnaSINE in the genome of A. anguilla. To do this, the sequences obtained during our previous RNA-Seq investigations (Baillon et al., 2015) (11,547 unique genes of known function were used) were compared and aligned to the draft genome of A. Anguilla (Henkel et al., 2012 ) (Evalue threshold 10 À30 ). These results were compared to those obtained by carrying out alignment analyses between UnaL2 or UnaSINE and the draft genome of A. anguilla (Evalue threshold 10 À10 ). We then selected the coding sequences that were located at a maximum of 1 kb to UnaL2 or UnaSINE. In order to not bias the functional analysis, redundant sequences were discarded to retain only one sequence for a given gene. Finally, a functional analysis of the selected sequences was performed with the Blast2go software (Conesa et al., 2005) using Gene Ontology annotation.
body_text.section: Genetic data treatment

body_text.text: For each fish, a liver sample of 20 mg (wet weight) was homogenized in 600 mL of ice-cold RTL buffer (Qiagen) with 6 mL of bmercaptoethanol using a tissue homogenizer for 30s (Mixer Mill MM 200, Retsch) . Following centrifugation, DNA and RNA were extracted from the homogenate using the AllPrep DNA/RNA kit (Qiagen) according to manufactures' guidelines. DNA concentrations as well as purity were determined by spectrophotometry (Take3, Epoch, Biotek). Quantification of single cytosine percent methylation at specific sites in the UnaL2 and UnaSINE RTs was then performed using the bisulfite-pyrosequencing method. First, 500 ng of DNA were bisulfite converted using the MethylEdge Bisulfite Conversion System (Promega) according to manufactures' guidelines. Then, 15 ng of bisulfite converted DNA was amplified by PCR using the PyroMark PCR kit (Qiagen) according to manufactures' instructions. Cycling conditions were as follows: 10-min initial denaturation step at 95 C, followed by 45 cycles of 94 C for 30 s, 30 s at optimal annealing temperature of primers (56 C for UnaL2 and 59 C for UnaSINE), 30 s at 72 C, 10 min of final elongation at 72 C. Pyrosequencing of biotinylated PCR products was performed by means of the PyroMark Q48 Autoprep (Qiagen) and specific pyrosequencing primers (Table S1 ). Average DNA methylation levels of CpN sites were quantified using the PyroMark Q48 autoprep software (Qiagen). For UnaL2, three CpG sites were analyzed. For UnaSINE, two CpG sites and one CpA site were analyzed. In addition, for each RT, in order to assay the conversion efficiency of the bisulfite treatment the average methylation level of one CpT site was measured. Indeed, while the preferential site of non-CpG methylation is CpA (especially in the case of RTs), CpT and CpC sites are mostly not methylated (Ichiyanagi et al., 2013) . For both RTs, the average methylation level of this control site was lower than 5% (i.e. corresponding to the detection limit), indicating a good conversion efficiency. Examples of pyrograms are available in Fig. S2 .
body_text.section: Quantitative analysis of methylation levels

body_text.text: For each fish, total RNA was extracted as described above (section 2.5). In order to avoid a potential contamination of RNA by DNA, total RNA was treated with DNAseI (Qiagen) according to the manufacturer's recommendations.
body_text.section: Quantitative analysis of transcription level

body_text.text: For each sample, RNA quality was evaluated by electrophoresis on a 1% agarose gel and concentrations as well as purity were determined by spectrophotometry (Take3, Epoch, Biotek). Firststrand cDNA was synthesized from 1 mg of total RNA using the GoScript Reverse Transcription System (Promega), according to the manufacturer's instructions. Following the reverse transcriptase reaction, cDNA was diluted 10-fold. Real-time PCR reactions were then performed in an MX3000P (Stratagene; 95 C for 10 min, followed by 40 cycles of 95 C for 15 s and 60 C for 30 s and 72 C for 30 s). Each 20 mL reaction contained 12.5 mL of GoTaq qPCR master mix (Promega), 5 mL template and the specific primer pairs at a final concentration of nM each. The reaction specificity was determined for each reaction by gel electrophoresis and from the dissociation curve of the PCR product. This was obtained by following the SyberGreen fluorescence level during a gradual heating of the PCR products from 60 to 95 C. Amplification efficiencies for all primer sets were calculated; all values proved to be sufficient to allow direct comparison of amplification plots according to the DDCt method (Livak and Schmittgen, 2001) . Relative quantification of gene expression was achieved by concurrent amplification of the b-actin endogenous control. Hence, during our experiment, total RNAs were quantified and 1 mg was used to be reverse-transcribed. During the subsequent qPCR amplifications, the output cycle corresponding to the b-actin was examined. No significant difference was observed on the output cycle of b-actin among fish from the four sampling sites (p > 0.05), demonstrating the relevance of the b-actin as reference gene in our conditions.
body_text.section: Quantitative analysis of transcription level

body_text.text: The relationships between RT methylation and transcription levels, phenotypic traits and environmental factors were investigated by means of Principal Component Analysis (PCA) and Spearman's Rank Correlation Analysis (SRCA) due to the nonlinearity and/or the non-homoscedasticity of the data. We also created classes of animals according to their transcription level of UnaL2_5 0 UTR by using the quantile function. Fish were classified in 3 groups by using the 33.33 and 66.66 percentile: (i) a class called "low", gathering fish with the lowest transcription level of UnaL2_5 0 UTR; (ii) a class called "intermediate", gathering fish with intermediate transcription level of UnaL2_5 0 UTR and (iii) a class called "high" gathering fish with the highest transcription level of UnaL2_5 0 UTR. Then, comparisons among fish groups from different classes were performed by analysis of variance (ANOVA), after checking assumptions of normality (Kolmogorov-Smirnov) and homoscedasticity of the error terms (Levene). When the assumptions were not met as deduced from ad-hoc tests, we used box-cox data transformations or the nonparametric KruskalÀWallis test. If significant effects were detected, the Bonferroni or Dunn-Bonferroni test were used to determine whether means between pairs of samples were significantly different from one another. Comparisons of variances among groups were performed using the Levene test after checking assumption of normality (Kolmogorov-Smirnov). Comparisons of proportions (sex distribution among classes) were performed using the Chi squared test and the Monte Carlo method using 5000 permutations followed by the Marascuilo procedure to compare proportions among them. Computations were performed using STATISTICA version 6.1 software (StatSoft) and XLSTAT (Addinsoft version 2012.6.08). Numerical results are given as means ± SE.
body_text.section: Statistical analyses

body_text.text: Although lower values of DNA methylation levels of UnaL2 were observed in fish from GAR and DOR in comparison to fish from CER or GIR, no significant differences (p > 0.05) were observed among sites for the three CpG sites analyzed ( Fig. 2A ). This could be explained by a high inter-individual variability, especially among fish from the CER site. For UnaSINE, no significant differences (p > 0.05) were observed among sites (Fig. 2B) .
body_text.section: Differential DNA methylation and transcription of RTs among sampling sites

body_text.text: Concerning transcription analyses, in order to more strictly link potential change in RT transcription levels to RTs activation, three fragments of both UnaSINE and UnaL2 were amplified and quantified (Fig. S1 ). Indeed, RT sequences in genomes are in most cases truncated and RT fragments are observed in protein-coding mRNA 3 0 UTR as well as in many long non-coding RNA (lncRNAs, Elbary et al., 2016) . For example, Alu elements (i.e. a SINE) are present in 5.7% of human mRNA 3 0 UTR (Faulkner et al., 2009) . The transcription levels of the different PCR products of UnaSINE or UnaL2 were highly correlated among themselves. For UnaSINE, the Spearman's rank correlation coefficients (r) between UnaSINE_a, UnaSINE_c and UnaSINE_ac varied from 0.947 to 0.964 (p < 0.05). For UnaL2, r varied from 0.941 to 0.976 (p < 0.05, see Table S2 ). This reinforces the fact that the changes observed among sites are mainly associated to RT activation rather than to only changes in RT fragments associated to coding mRNA. In addition, the transcription levels of UnaSINE and UnaL2 were highly correlated among themselves (r varied from 0.848 to 0.953, p < 0.05). This appears consistent with the fact that UnaSINE is mobilized by UnaL2 as demonstrated by Kajikawa et al. (2005) in HeLa cells.
body_text.section: Differential DNA methylation and transcription of RTs among sampling sites

body_text.text: Significant differences in RT transcription levels were observed among sites (Fig. 2C and D) . Fish from GAR and DOR presented significantly higher transcription levels of UnaL2 and UnaSINE than fish from CER ( Fig. 2C and D) . Concerning protein-coding mRNA, i.e. rere and sox6 transcripts, the transcription level of rere was significantly higher in fish from DOR in comparison to fish from CER and GIR. For sox6, fish from DOR presented significantly higher values than fish from the other sites ( Fig. 2E ). It is difficult to determine what kind of stress or environmental factors or even intrinsic factors triggered changes in RT transcription levels among sites. Indeed, the four sampling sites presented different profiles of metal and organic pollution (see Baillon et al., 2015; Laporte et al., 2016 and Pannetier et al., 2016) as well as different salinities and temperatures (Table 1 ). In addition, intrinsic parameters such as age are known to trigger changes in RT transcription levels, the expression level of RTs increasing with ageing in mammalian somatic tissues (De Cecco et al., 2013) . In our case, fish from GAR were significantly older than fish from CER or DOR (Table 1) .
body_text.section: Differential DNA methylation and transcription of RTs among sampling sites

body_text.text: In order to link the observed changes to phenotypic traits, we first realized a principal component analysis (PCA; Fig. S3 ) using the DNA methylation and transcription levels of RTs and the variables described in Table 2 . Principal component 1 (PC1) was mainly defined by organic pollutant concentrations, growth indices and the transcription level of RTs. Thus, the PCA analysis highlighted the importance of these three groups of variables as well as a relationship among them. Among RTs, UnaL2_5 0 UTR was found to have the most important contribution to the PC1 (Table S3 ) as well as the most significant correlations not only with all growth indices but also with the concentrations of some pollutants in eels. The most significant correlation between UnaL2 transcription levels and growth indices was found between UnaL2_5 0 UTR transcript and back-calculated length at 3 years (r ¼ À0.565, p < 0.001; Table S2 ). Among pollutants, the most significant correlations were observed with the concentration of PCB153 (r ¼ 0.529, p ¼ 0.002) and 4.4 0 DDE (i.e. a metabolite of DDT, r ¼ 0.514, p ¼ 0.006). UnaL2_5-0 UTR was also correlated with the transcription level of rere and sox6 (r ¼ 0.617 and 0.563; p < 0.001 and p ¼ 0.001, respectively). We must add that the contribution of the methylation levels of both UnaL2 and UnaSINE to the PCA was very limited (Table S3) . Moreover, no significant correlations were observed between RT DNA methylation levels and their corresponding transcription levels (Table S2 ). This appears consistent with the fact that RTs can be activated by stress either directly or through the arousal of their epigenetic control (Rey et al., 2016) but also with the mode of action of epigenetic marks. Covalent addition of a methyl group to cytosine influences the condensation level of chromatin and the accessibility of transcription factors to their binding sites, modulating the plasticity and/or the reaction norm of a gene (Aubin-Horth and Renn, 2009; Dixon et al., 2014) . Thus, a correlation analysis is probably not the most appropriate method to investigate the relationship between DNA methylation, transcription and phenotypic traits.
body_text.section: RTs, environmental factors and phenotypic traits

body_text.text: In order to deepen the relationships between RT DNA methylation levels, RT transcription levels, phenotypic traits and environmental factors, we also created 3-class typology of animals according to their transcription levels of UnaL2_5 0 UTR. A significant up-regulation of UnaSINE and UnaL2 was observed along the three classes (Table 2) . No difference in age was observed among the three classes. The upregulation of RTs in fish from the low to the high class was nevertheless associated with (i) a significant decrease in the DNA methylation levels of UnaL2_CG2, (ii) a significant increase in OCP and especially 4,4 0 DDE concentrations, (iii) a significant decrease of all growth indices and (iv) a significant up-regulation of both rere and sox6 transcripts. Taken together, our results show that fish with high transcription levels of RTs presented low DNA methylation levels of UnaL2, low growth indices and high contamination levels. The distribution of fish among these classes according to their site of origin is presented in Fig. 3 . The low class was constituted by fish from CER, GIR and GAR. The intermediate class was constituted by fish of all sampling sites while the high class was equally constituted by fish from DOR and GAR. Thus, the high class was the only class that was exclusively constituted by fish from freshwater environments. This could explain, at least in part (and if we consider that eels are mostly resident; further discussed below), why fish from the high class presented significantly lower growth indices than fish from the low class. Indeed, eels grow faster in brackish than in freshwater, even under experimental conditions (Cairns et al., 2009; Côt e et al., 2009; Daverat et al., 2012) . However, salinity alone cannot explain the differences observed in term of RT transcription levels, RT methylation levels or even growth indices among the three classes. For example, while no significant differences were observed in growth indices between fish from the high and the intermediate classes, the intermediate class was constituted by fish from all sampling sites (including 36.4% of fish from freshwater sites and 63.6% fish from brackish water sites). Laporte et al. (2016) recently reported within-generation polygenic selection (RAD-Seq) in response to organic and metal contaminants and more precisely in response to PCB153, 4.4 0 DDE and Se exposure in the same eels. Interestingly, PCB153 and 4.4 0 DDE were the two organic pollutants that were the most correlated with the transcription level of UnaL2_5 0 UTR and 4.4 0 DDE was the only pollutant for which significant differences in bioaccumulation levels were observed among the different UnaL2 classes. In other words, among the three contaminants that were previously pointed out to be major selective agents in our sampling sites, two were also associated with the highest RT transcription levels. This observation supports that RT activation is associated to pollution and toxic conditions (Roling et al., 2004) .
body_text.section: RTs, environmental factors and phenotypic traits

body_text.text: There is increasing experimental evidence that some TEs exhibit abiotic and biotic stress-responsive transcription or movement especially in plants (Capy et al., 2000; Wessler, 1996 ; Makarevitch et al., 2015; Lish, 2009) and to a lesser extent in fungi, corals, insects, crustaceans, fish and mammals (Barbosa et al., 2014; Zeh et al., 2009; Roling et al., 2004) . Moreover, it is now recognized that environmental factors, such as nutritional quality or exposure to pollutants, can strongly affect the epigenetic status of cells (Vandegehuchte and Janssen, 2011; Pierron et al., 2014b; Feil and Fraga, 2012) and notably the methylation state of RTs (Pierron et al., 2014a; Jirtle and Skinner, 2007; Dolinoy, 2008) . DNA methylation is an epigenetic mark commonly associated with transcriptional repression and that can be conserved during cell division. Moreover, stress-induced changes in RT DNA methylation levels can have long-lasting effects on the phenotype of organisms by affecting the transcription of adjacent genes and this, even after the environmental cue that induced these changes is removed (Aubin-Horth and Renn, 2009; Dolinoy, 2008) . In the present study, we found that the transcription levels of RTs were positively correlated with the contamination levels of eels. We also found that the up-regulation of RTs among UnaL2_5 0 UTR classes was associated with lower DNA methylation levels of UnaL2. The upregulation of RT transcription levels and the decrease in RT DNA methylation levels were further associated with (i) lower growth indices and (ii) an up-regulation of two genes involved in development and cell fate, i.e. rere (Wang et al., 2008) and sox6 (Cantu' et al., 2011) . Rere encodes a protein that acts as transcriptional co-repressor during embryonic development (Zeh et al., 2009) . Sox6 has been suggested to act both as activator or repressor (Cantu' et al., 2011) . Sox6 by recruiting ctbp2 (C-terminal binding protein 2), a gene that we previously found to be up-regulated in wild contaminated eels collected in the same sampling sites (Baillon et al., 2015) , is known to repress transcription of the fibroblast growth factor 3 (fgf-3). Taken together, our findings appear consistent with the fact that TE activation in response to stress (i) is associated to changes in their methylation status and (ii) is known to decrease the host fitness (Casacuberta and Gonz alez, 2013) . On another side, given the recent findings that highlighted the key influence of TEs as regulators of gene expression (Elbarbary et al., 2016; Faulkner et al., 2009) , it is intriguing to speculate that TE activation not only triggers detrimental effects but also plays a role in the responsive capacity of their hosts in face of environmental challenges (Casacuberta and Gonz alez, 2013) . A consequence of new TE insertions is the creation of new genetic innovation that can lead to an increased resistance to xenobiotics (Casacuberta and Gonz alez, 2013; Zeh et al., 2009; Schlenke and Begun, 2004; Aminetzachet al., 2005) . Concerning the contribution of RT RNAs in the "direct" physiological response to stress, the question has received less attention. Even so, an emerging body of evidence indicates that RNAs of both SINEs and LINEs can regulate gene expression at different levels (Elbarbary et al., 2016) . For example, SINEs (Alu RNAs) were found to act as transacting transcriptional repressor (i.e. inhibiting mRNA transcription of specific mRNA genes) during the cellular heat shock response in human cells and mouse (Mariner et al., 2008) . More stirring, a few recent cutting-edge studies have shown how RTs shape specific stem cell gene expression (Robbez-Masson and Rowe, 2015; Ohnuki et al., 2014) . In vitro studies have shown that TEs are up-regulated during the reprogramming of human primary hepatocytes (Friedli et al., 2014) . During reprogramming, differentiated somatic cells (mature hepatocytes) turn into induced pluripotent stem cells (iPSCs). Moreover, recent findings have reported a crucial role of Alu elements in association with sox genes in cancer drug resistance. These resistant cancer cell lines shared some common features with iPSCs (Lin et al., 2015) . Hepatic progenitor cells (HPCs) play a major role in liver repair and regeneration and are known to be highly resistant to xenobiotics (Ros et al., 2003) . In this view, we must add that sox gene family members are representative of stemness-related genes, promoting cell survival and maintenance of stem/progenitor cells (Ohta et al., 2013; Lin et al., 2015) . Another argument supporting an important functional role of these RTs relies on the conservation of the UnaL2 and UnaSINE sequences. Indeed, although radiation and speciation of A. anguilla and A. japonica is estimated at about 30 million years ago (Aoyama, 2009) , the sequence of UnaL2 and UnaSINE were found to be highly conserved between the two species (Figs. S4 and S5) . In addition, we found that the genes located at the proximity of UnaL2 or UnaSINE at the genomic level (Figs. S6 and S7) were at the same time involved in anatomical structure development (GO term 0048856) or regulation of biological quality (GO term 0065008) but also in response to stress (GO term 0006950) or response to chemical stimulus (GO term 0042221). Finally, it was recently proposed that the interplay between TEs and epigenetic components constitute an integrative molecular engine that allows organisms to fine-tune phenotypes in a real-time fashion (Rey et al., 2016) , playing a key role in the rapid adaptive phenotypic responses to stress. In this view, significant differences in the interindividual variability of UnaL2 methylation levels were observed both among sampling sites and Unal2_5 0 UTR classes ( Fig. 2A and Table 2 ). In both analyses, the least contaminated fish (i.e. eels from CER or from the low class) presented the highest inter-individual variabilities. For example, a significant and gradual decrease in the variance of the DNA methylation levels of UnaL2_CG2 was observed in fish from the low to the high class (Fig. 4A ). This could be explained by different life history traits. Indeed, although yellow (i.e. somatic growth phase) eels are considered to be mostly residents, previous investigations showed that a fraction of eels inhabiting brackish waters can move between coastal/estuarine and freshwater systems once or more during their growth phase (mainly at early life, until the age of 2e3 years). However, previous investigations carried out on eels from the Arcachon Bay found that eels from CER are residents (Daverat and Tom as, 2006) . We must note that A. anguilla is a panmictic species with random dispersal of larvae. European eels reproduce once in their life in the Sargasso Sea, from where larvae drift back toward the European coasts following oceanic currents. When larvae reach the continental slope, they metamorphose into young eels that penetrate continental habitats and complete their growth phase in a large range of systems (lagoons, estuaries, marshes, rivers, lakes and streams).
body_text.section: Up-regulation of RTs: unintended changes or adaptive response?

body_text.text: The genome of European eels is thus homogenized by gene flow that removes any effects of diversifying selection from each generation, preventing genetic adaptation to local conditions (Pujolar et al., 2014) . The loss of variability from fish of the low class to fish of the high class could be thus viewed as a result of an intensive environmental constraint. This appears consistent with our observation that RT up-regulation was associated with two pollutants (PCB153 and 4.4 0 DDE) that we previously identified as the major selective agents in eels from these sites, supporting a role of RTs in increasing fish survival (Laporte et al., 2016) . This loss of variability at the epigenetic level was instead associated with an increased variability in UnaL2 transcription levels (Fig. 4B) . Such an effect is consistent with the general hypothesis for which weak DNA methylation levels facilitate environmentally responsive expression (Dixon et al., 2014) . Low methylation levels can increase transcription plasticity by allowing greater access of transcription factors to binding sites. Through this mechanism, DNA methylation could allow the emergence of variable transcriptomic phenotypes that are required for rapid acclimation in selective environments and, potentially, adaption in the case of new RT insertions. This is also consistent with the fact that whereas no significant difference in mean UnaL2_CG2 methylation levels was observed between fish from the intermediate and high class, both the variance and mean of UnaL2 transcription levels were significantly higher in fish from the high class in comparison to fish from the intermediate class.
body_text.section: Up-regulation of RTs: unintended changes or adaptive response?

body_text.text: Fish from the high class presented 2-fold higher concentrations in 4.4 0 DDE and PCB153 than fish from the intermediate class and significantly higher concentrations of OCPs than fish from the intermediate class. In addition, fish from the high class, in comparison to fish from the intermediate class, only come from freshwater sites. Several authors qualified the migration of eels into freshwaters as paradoxical, given the fitness penalty imposed by relatively slow growth in freshwaters and the fact that this migration is facultative to complete their particular life cycle (Cairns et al., 2009; Daverat and Tom as, 2006; Edeline, 2007) . Freshwater appear to be an unfavorable or, at least, not optimal condition for European eel growth. Thus, high and highly variable UnaL2 transcription levels were associated to the worst environmental conditions for eels; i.e. high contamination levels associated to low salinity in our case study.
body_text.section: Up-regulation of RTs: unintended changes or adaptive response?

body_text.text: We thus propose that the up-regulation of RTs in fish liver under stress conditions could have both detrimental and beneficial implications, affecting eel growth but promoting eel resistance to environmental stressors such as pollutants. Nevertheless, as the Fig. 4 . Box plots of the DNA methylation levels of UnaL2_CG2 (left panel) and UnaL2_5 0 UTR transcription levels (right panel) among the different UnaL2_5 0 UTR classes (low, intermediate (inter) and high). Results of Levene tests are indicated on the graphs and significant differences in variances among classes are in bold. Size of UnaL2_5 0 UTR classes were: low ¼ 10; intermediate ¼ 11; high ¼ 11.
body_text.section: Up-regulation of RTs: unintended changes or adaptive response?

body_text.text: somatic growth rate of fish is an important factor influencing their reproductive success, affecting their size at maturity and fecundity (Denney et al., 2002) , RTs could represent interesting environmentsensitive molecular elements allowing to link pollutant-or more generally stress-induced molecular events to adverse outcomes at the individual and even, population levels. This appears especially true for European eels as their sexual maturation (silvering) is mainly triggered by size, rather than age (Svedaung et al., 1996) . Rapid growth hastens the single reproductive opportunity of these semelparous fish and decreases their vulnerability to natural or anthropogenic mortality (Lamson et al., 2009) .
body_text.section: Up-regulation of RTs: unintended changes or adaptive response?

body_text.text: F.Pierron et al. / Environmental Pollution 245 (2019) 494e503

back_matter.text: Val erie David and Mohamedou Sow are thanked for their advice on statistical analyses. This work was also supported by the Investments for the future Program, within the Cluster of Excellence COTE (ANR-10-LABX-45).

FIGREF1.text: Change in (i) the DNA methylation levels of three different CpN sites in UnaL2 (A) and UnaSINE (B) and (ii) the transcription levels of UnaL2 (C), UnaSINE (D) and coding genes (E) in the liver of wild fish captured in four sampling sites (CER, GIR, GAR, DOR). Values are presented as means ± SE; n ¼ 8. Bars sharing same-case letters do not differ significantly (p > 0.05).

FIGREF2.text: Proportion of fish belonging to the different UnaL2_5 0 UTR classes according to their site of origin. Three classes (low, intermediate or high transcription level of UnaL2_5 0 UTR) and four sampling sites (CER, GIR, GAR, DOR) were compared. Size of UnaL2_5 0 UTR classes were: low ¼ 10; intermediate ¼ 11; high ¼ 11. Height fish were used per sampling site.

TABREF1.text: Change in liver DNA methylation levels, transcription levels, morphometric and growth indices, liver metals concentrations and muscle organic pollutants concentrations in eels belonging to the different UnaL2_5 0 UTR classes(low, intermediate, high). Except sex (female or undifferentiated, expressed as percentage), data are expressed as means ± SD. Variables that varied significantly among fish classes are in bold; means designated with different letters differ significantly (p < 0.05). Size of UnaL2_5 0 UTR classes were: low ¼ 10; intermediate ¼ 11; high ¼ 11.
